utterances: There you go again.
When I hear your new ideas, I'm reminded of that ad.
'Where's the beef?'
Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice.
You don't have Nixon to kick around anymore.
I love those hockey moms.
You know, they say the difference between a hockey mom and a pit bull - lipstick.
But I'm the decider.
(SOUNDBITE OF HOWARD DEAN SCREAMING)
On Wednesdays, NPR political editor Ken Rudin joins us to talk politics.
And as usual, there is a lot to talk to about.
Senate tsuris in Illinois, Minnesota and New York, but Colorado managed to smooth succession, at least so far.
Aides to the president-elect and the governor of New Mexico argue about who overlooked that minor detail about the federal investigation.
And we begin first, as always, with a trivia question.
Political junkie Ken Rudin joins us here is studio 3A.
Hey, Ken.
Hi, Neal.
Happy New Year.
And happy New Year to you.
Thank you so much.
Leon Panetta has been mentioned although not been officially announced as Obama's choice to head up the Central Intelligence Agency.
OK, name the three former CIA directors who ran for Congress.
So, if you think you know the identities of the three former Central Intelligence Agency directors who also ran for Congress, give us a call.
800-989-8255 is the phone number.
The e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
And, Ken, we have to begin with an apparent 180 from Senate Democrats on Roland Burris.
That's right.

The Harry Reid said from the beginning that no matter - if embattled governor - Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich decides to pick somebody to replace Barack Obama to that vacant Senate seat, the Senate Democrats will just not seat him or her.
I mean, he made that clear.
Then Blagojevich surprised everybody by naming Roland Burris last week, which was a remarkable bit of...
Theater, I think Roland Burris called it.
Theater, exactly.
And now, there's a lot of pressure on Senate Democrats to name Burris because Burris has not been implicated in any wrong doing.
He's legally qualified to serve as senator.
And Blagojevich basically still - he's still the governor.
He hasn't been impeached.
He hasn't been removed.
He hasn't been indicted yet.
He hasn't been convicted of anything.
I haven't checked the wires lately.
No.
Nothing's changed.
So, matter of fact, if you listen to Patrick Fitzgerald, it sounds like it's going to take a long time.
Before the indictment is forthcoming, he may be impeached by the Illinois legislature before that.
That's true.
So, as of now, at least as of this moment, he is the governor, certainly in his legal rights to name the successor.
Now, Harry Reid and Senate Democrats argue that, well, you have to have two signatures on the certification, and that includes the secretary of state of Illinois, Jesse White.
Jesse White has refused to sign because he feels that Blagojevich is corrupt.
Well, I think that most banks are unfortunately in similar circumstances.
It is hard for me to say whose, you know, the worst off and who's better off.
But, we had a lending spree that was unprecedented where anything goes.
You know, you had people were not - had no income documentation, not asset documentation, no job verification, were given loans.
And it was all about generating fees on those loans, to the companies who made them.
Now the costs of this really mania, that generated so many millions of dollars for so many people in these private sector companies, is now coming a cropper.
Gretchen, how does this compare to the savings and loan debacle which cost tax payers hundreds of billions of dollars?
Well, it's far larger, and it is far more complex.
In the savings and loan disaster of the early 90's, late 80's.
You were really mostly talking about commercial real estate and multi-family homes.

And those are much easier to take over and analyze, you know, whether the financial statements, the cash flows that were generated by the rents of those buildings were adequate to meet the borrowings that they had taken on.
We are now talking about single family homes.
This is not something that you can work out on mass, or in large swabs like you could in the savings and loans crisis.
So it's far more complicated.
So it sounds a lot more frightening actually, to be frank about it how scared should we be?
This is really one of the most meddlesome and enormous problems that I think we have had to face.
There's just plenty of blame to go around, but I think we have to face the failings and really admit them and then try set up practices, and policies that will make sure that won't happen again.
New York Times business columnist, Gretchen Morgenson, thank you very much.
Any time.
In the last two days, we've seen the inauguration of a new president, the reaction to it and Donald Trump's reaction to the reaction.
Donald Trump took the oath of office on Friday in front of a crowd of supporters on the National Mall, and he did not like the reports that his crowd was smaller than several previous inaugurations.
Yesterday, at the CIA, he said this.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
But we had a massive field of people.
You saw that - packed.
I get up this morning.
I turn on one of the networks, and they show an empty field.
I said wait a minute, I made a speech.
I looked out, the field was - it looked like a million, million and a half people.
They showed a field where there were practically nobody standing there.
Also yesterday, hundreds of thousands of women marched in Washington and cities around the country and the world.
We're joined now by national political correspondent Mara Liasson.
Good morning, Mara.
Hi, Lulu.
Let's start with those marches yesterday.
What's the significance, in your view, of events like this?
Will the protests have any effect on President Trump and his administration?

That depends on whether the protests turn into the Tea Party or Occupy Wall Street, whether these marchers stay engaged, turn out to vote in 2018 and 2020 for Democratic candidates - or if they fade away.
I think Donald Trump has really said it all this morning when he tweeted, quote, ""we just had an election.
Why didn't these people vote?"" Trump also does not like the size of his assets questioned, whether they are buildings, finances or especially crowds.
You heard him at the CIA yesterday.
And today he also tweeted that 31 million people watched the inauguration on television, which he said was 11 million more than four years ago.

And yesterday, you can see that these marches are already having an effect on the Trump administration because his press secretary, Sean Spicer, came to the briefing room at the White House to admonish reporters that they had been underplaying the size of Trump's crowds.
Here's a little bit of that.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
This was the largest audience to ever witness an inauguration, period, both in person and around the globe.
We should say here, Mara, that was a lie essentially.
President Trump's first full day in office, he made an important stop to the CIA.
Tell us why he went and what he did there.
The purpose of that stop was to reassure the intelligence community that they had his full support, which he did say.
He said, I'm with you 1,000 percent.
This is after he had compared them to Nazi Germany.
He stood in front of the Wall of Heroes at the CIA - those are the plaques for CIA agents who died in service to the country - and then he started lashing out at the media.
He blamed them for creating the feud between him and the intelligence community.
And as you just heard, he talked about the size of his crowds.
Let's talk a little bit about Friday and the inaugural address.
Commentators are saying it's a speech like no other.
It was a speech like no other - very dark.
I think it was directed at his base.
And these kinds of speeches, very similar to the one he gave at the convention, have been very effective for him.

I think around the world, our allies blanched at his slogan, only America first - sounded like he was declaring an end to the American idea where America stands up for democratic values around the world and sees our economic and national security interests in a stable world with as many democracies as possible.
But what's interesting to me about the speech is, so far, the deafening silence from Republicans in Congress about the speech and the themes.
He really laid out a very different path for the Republican Party.
And so far, you aren't hearing a lot of Republicans saying, yes, America first - only America first is our new slogan.
And really, just in a few sentences, will these protests affect how President Trump will govern?
And given all the embarrassment in what's going in Illinois, the last thing the new Obama administration wanted was the taint of some kind of a scandal.
Richardson, again, has not been personally involved we don't think, although the investigation is still going on.
I think that depends on who co-opts who.
The Republican Party wants to manage Trump.
Trump wants to co-opt them, harness them for his new nationalist, protectionist agenda.
I think we'll see if he can pass that $1 trillion infrastructure plan.
But that being said, despite small crowds, despite low approval ratings, Donald Trump is in a very strong political position.
He has both houses of Congress, and he has a growing economy, growing GDP, shrinking unemployment, growing household incomes.
Now the question is, what will he do with it?
Mara Liasson, thanks so much.
Thank you.
